awd_abstract_narration:
The projects to be investigated are motivated by the following two different problems.  It is well known that sea ice in the Arctic is receding. Changes in climate are thought to be a contributing factor.  Therefore, it is important to understand if, when, and how daily temperatures in the Arctic region are impacting sea ice.  The second motivation comes from neuroscience. Is it possible to predict the decision a person makes based on biometric and neurophysiological responses, such as eye dilation observed over time or an EEG? The objectives in both examples are very different, however they are bound by a common theme; to understand how data observed over time (usually called a time series) affects an outcome of interest. These problems fall under the canopy of regression (a broad topic in statistics), which is a widely researched area in statistics. However, what distinguishes these problems from the classical regression framework is that the regressors have a well-defined structure, which is rarely exploited in most classical regression techniques. By modelling the time series, methods will be developed that exploit the structure of the time series. This will facilitate estimation in models that otherwise would not be possible. The approach will be used to identify salient periods in the time series that have the greatest impact on the outcome and can be used to physically interpret the data. 

In recent years, there has been a growing number of data sets, from a wide spectrum of applications ranging from the neurosciences to the geosciences, where an outcome is observed together with a time series that is believed to influence the outcome.  Despite the clear need in applications, there exists surprisingly few results that exploit the properties of a time series in the prediction of outcomes. This project will bridge this gap by developing regression methods that utilize the fact that the regressors are a time series or are spatially dependent.  To achieve these aims, many new statistical methods will be developed. In signal processing, deconvolution methods are often used to estimate the parameters of a two-sided linear filter. This is because the deconvolution is computationally very fast to implement. However, there has been very little exploration on the use of deconvolution methods within the framework of estimating regression parameters. This project will develop deconvolution techniques for (i) linear regression models, and (ii) generalized linear models and when the regressors are stationary and locally stationary. The focus will be on the realistic situation where the time series or spatial data is far larger than the number of responses.  Besides the computational simplicity of deconvolution, by isolating the Fourier transform of the regression coefficients, diagnostic tools to understand the nature of the underlying regression coefficients will be developed. For example, the methods can tell whether the coefficients are smooth, contain periodicities, or are sparse.  The project will develop inferential methods for parameter estimators that allow for uncertainty quantification, construction of confidence intervals, and tests for linear dependence. Included is a new technique for estimating the variance of the regression coefficients.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal in this project was to develop deconvolution methods for high dimension regression data where the regressors are time series. One well known example is the Toeplitz system of equations (which arise in many applications in electrical engineering, geosciences and time series). This system of equation is solved by inverting the Toeplitz matrix. If the dimension is large, inversion can be computationally costly. Instead, typically, the Toeplitz matrix is approximated by acirculant matrix. The circulant matrix has a very well understood spectral decomposition (the eigenvectors are the discrete Fourier basis), thus it is straightforward and computationally cheap to invert. It is this approximation that gives rise to the Whittle likelihood approximation of the classical Gaussian likelihood (commonly used in both time series and spatial statistics). However, the circulant approximation has the disadvantage that it is biased. In some situations, such as the Whittle likelihood this biasis negligible for sufficiently large samples. However, in other applications such as the Toeplitz system of equations the bias caused by using the circulant approximation is large and needs to be corrected using the classical Wiener-Hopf technique.


A major achievement in this project was to move away from orthogonal decompositions (such as the spectral decomposition). We show that a Toeplitz matrix (and indeed any other positive definite matrix) can be expressed as a biorthogonal decomposition. This representation is not unique. However, for Toeplitz matrix we show that the biorthogonal transformation associated with the Fourier basis was the Fourier basis plus an additional (interpretable) boundary correction term. This allowed us to rewrite the Gaussian likelihood in the so called frequency domain, and gives a simple and intuitive intepretation to the Whittle likelihood. This motivates the boundary corrected Whittle likelihood which has the computational simplicity of the classical Whittle likelihood but with additional advantage of a smaller bias. It also allowed us derive an alternative solution to the Toeplitz system equations. We showed the biorthogonal transform can also be used to correct for the bias in the periodgram.


From a theoretical perspective our results bridge the gap between so called frequency domain and time domain methods. They give insight into the frequency domain methods, which many practitioners find counterintuitive and consequently avoid. From a practical perspective, the proposed methods are computationally extremely fast and correct several types of biases that arise in time series. The hope is that the use of biorthogonal transformswill give rise to computationally fast tools that are simple to use.
